About Projects Résumé Coursework Blog Misc

Ziyue Yang

I'm a third-year undergraduate student at the University of Toronto, pursuing a degree in Computer Science, Statistics, and Mathematics. My interests intersect software engineering, machine learning, and data science.

Previously, I interned as an iOS developer under KWG Group Holdings at the Cohesion group, where I majorly worked with Swift and React Native. I led a group at Bigtheta, demonstrated software design principles and built web applications. I'm also involved in the LearnAI program at UofTAI since September 2020.

I constantly seek opportunities, looking forward to making positive impacts and gaining valuable experience from the industry, while maintaining a healthy work-life balance.



Projects

§MNIST Classifier

MNIST classifier implemented with numpy only. This project emphasizes the understanding of fundamental level machine learning concepts and usage.

code

PIRLS

Model built using parsnip engine that computes the logistic Lasso using coordinate descent on the penalized iteratively reweighted least squares algorithm.

code | vignette

Image Stitcher

I implemented functions in a module that takes image inputs and transform them into cross-stitch patterns. The module uses K-means algorithm to cluster images into a chosen number of groups based on the RGB information. Helper methods on choosing the ideal number of clusters are provided.

code | vignette

UniMart

code | demo

Ziyue Yang, Won Kim

Agenda

Android calendar app which allows multiple users to store event data locally. Features include searching events by names, creating events based on given frequencies, and tagging events. I majorly designed and implemented the Android GUI. I also programmed SQLite database helper to query user data. This app was developed in Winter 2020 in my software design course.


Ziyue Yang, Yunlong Chen, Xi Zheng, Juliana Chu, Yeuk Lam Ng, Jiajun Chen

code

FPV Navigator

First-person view navigator implemented in C++ inspired by the algorithm in Wolfenstein 3D. The algorithm takes an input of 2-dimensional maps made up of blocks and spaces, and renders 3D spaces based on the maps. This navigator allows player to "walk around" in the command line-rendered space.

code
